description:
I've been to so many eagles the funny part is that non of them are a chain nor are they related to one another. 
Okay so for some reason "The SF Eagle" is the biggest one so far.. let's just get that out of the way. 
Huge dance floor because let's face it leather queens love to boogie too right ?
Place has a beautiful outside patio that reminds me a rough porn scene or something sorta reminds me of the "SLAMMER." Out here in LA. 
It's a little pricey compared to other hole in the wall places but it's sf.. I guess. 
Had a good time day drinking here met cool people. 
They have 3 restrooms and a pissing tub which is fantastic!
author: Roket K.

description: Worst place to go to during Folsom. Staff at door are very rude and once u pay and then try to leave they will let you stand in line even after getting stamped
author: Karim S.

description: Anyone who tells you San Francisco is accepting and all-inclusive clearly hasn't been to Eagle. Unfriendly, slow bartenders unless you fit into their ideal. Cliquey, snobby patrons. Unless you fit into the bear mold people are not friendly. Expensive, over-priced drinks. If you go there have a lot of cash on you and be sure to fit their criteria.
author: Thom B.

description:
Eagle bars are all over the world including San Diego, Chicago (former city I lived in), Los Angeles and of course San Francisco.  It's a go to name for most leather bars.  None of them are connected except for two things, the name (with either the city name added) and that for the most part a leather bar.  I say that because I have visited most of these bars and some are more part of the leather community than others.  They have to survive in the current world of Social media wherein gay bars have been replaced by Social apps such as Grindr, Scruff and Recon.  Nothing really replaces face to face meeting groups in bars but some pooh pooh this connection.  They mostly seek an ideal meeting place online or regular sports bars or other venues to connect.

After that mini lecture, let's examine this particular bar.  I review most places I go to but hesitate to do most bars.  Obviously, when it comes to personal choices, we don't have to reveal all of our activities to the world including places that most people don't frequent.  But Yelp has become a go to for visitors in the urban landscape, so I share my own experiences in bits and pieces but almost always on places I have at least been once or twice a year (out of town).  Most of my travels are for pleasure and family and not for business, so I visit to relax.  

If you are familiar with what SF Eagle is, then here is my take.  It's spacious with half of the place almost outdoors.  It gets busier on times when there is a specific event related to leather or the leather community is happening.  That being said, this only means more visitors and not necessarily the same people it would cater to.  Although we all want to be inclusive, the idea that someone in their shorts after a long afternoon out can come into to the same bar where most people are dressed for the event makes it different in my eyes.  No issues with this until the same people complain about service, environment and of course how this bar is not what they thought it could be.  I have been to many bars, I can't say most of them would not be considered the ideal place - noise, spilled beers, bathrooms with possibly hygiene issues and of course a large variety of clientele from the curious, to the extreme.  I have seen the SF Eagle busy and quiet.  However, I always come in with my expectations tamped down.  I know how to be patient on busy nights and not worry if the place is empty (less crowded).  I enjoy each visit because I don't try to idealize a place.

SF Eagle can be what you want it to be, a different place to meet friends and strangers.  You have to come in with expectations that if it is a leather event, there might be men/women in gear (leather) in various forms.  On quieter times, seeing people in casual clothes is expected with a mix of some other leather persons.  Out of-town visitors seek similar places (like I do) in other cities they have visited - Berlin, London, Paris etc for like minded folks.  If you are one of those, always check the website.  If nothing is going on during that week or weekend, don't expect much but if its a particular event, prepare accordingly (crowds,mixed groups of people).
author: Melanio F.

description: I've been to the eagle a few times with friends and always enjoyed it. The bartenders are attentive and kind, the drinks are good and the atmosphere is nice. It's always been a sort of neutral place for me but tonight my expectations were greatly exceeded. The whole energy tonight was great the bartenders were especially great, refilling a drink that someone had knocked over by accident. Also tonight I accidently left my phone in the bathroom and within ten minutes one of the security guards CJ had found the phone and returned it to me. CJ was fabulous and I really appreciated how he helped me but also how kind he was about the whole thing!
author: Rose E.

description:
Why, when the entire length of the bar is unoccupied, do people line up single file behind the cash registers? It makes zero sense to me when the bar is long to accommodate as many people as possible. Perhaps it's just a pet peeve of mine, but dang, get a move on.

The whole place is about the outside patio. While it's very large and impressive it's not very welcoming. Nor is it conducive with moving freely because it gets SO packed. While that might be the scene some enjoy, I don't think it's fun to squeeze.

On the positive side, the bartenders are sexy af. Eye candy never hurt anybody so that's a good thing. There is a decent selection of beers and drinks and they aren't overpriced, which sometimes you get at a place like this. It would be a cool spot to hang out if it weren't always so crowded.

I'd call this a quick stop-in place. One and done, then move along to somewhere else. It's nice for a hot minute, but that's about it.
author: Richard R.

description: So, not only is this place awesome and one of the best bars I the city, the staff is amazing. My friend lost his wallet; and the gonzo security staff of the SF Eagle found it in the middle of 12th street and returned it to him fully intact. 5 out of 5 stars. Would highly recommend. Ask for Beth--she's kind of amazing.
author: Allen J.

description: Great space..Great Staff. Clean. Easy to get drinks. Hit Bartenders & Patrons. Drinks not overpriced. Keep up the good work.
author: Ken H.

description:
Last time I was here, some power-tripping staff member saw fit to bully myself and other patrons and single-handedly ruined the night.

We came hoping to see some friends and were having a good time until this big guy with tattooed legs and a hostile attitude kept circling around the area and started picking on some patrons across the patio from us. He would come up with excuses to harass them, such as accusing them of spitting on the floor because one of them coughed, and trying to intimidate them without any provocation.

I figured it was none of my business and stayed out of it. However, when they left, he moved on to targeting me, apparently deprived of an outlet for his frustration.
Still trying to have a nice night with my partner, I was lying my head on her shoulder when this guy marches over to us and orders me not to "have my head down."

Now, I can understand if the management doesn't want drunk people passed out around the club, but I was neither inebriated nor passed out- I was merely enjoying a tender moment with my partner. Still willing to give him benefit of the doubt I agreed not to "have my head down," and tried to press on through his aggressive interruption.

He came back as I leaned in while kissing my partner, prying us apart to bark at me, threatening to THROW ME OUT for disobeying him.
That's right- he wanted to throw me out for tilting my face downward while I kissed my partner.

My night was ruined. This staff member seemed to clearly be trying to twist the club rules to bully anyone he could wield power over, and I felt under attack. We would have left then and there if we weren't there with the playing DJ.

How was I supposed to relax with this menacing guy shooting me daggers as he patrolled around, waiting for me to slip?

Very bad experience.
author: Nathaniel K.

description: I loved this bar. It was fun. A little empty but that's not the bars fault. Pricey but worth it. Love a good leather bear place. The drinks were good, they were potent. I love drinking and men so it was perfect for me. Hallelujah
author: Ryan F.

description:
I only drink dark beers. 
Asked for a dark IPA drink, it was so lite as if it is mixed with water. So asked for a glass of Guinness beer, also it tasted nothing like Guinness beer.
DARK BEERS DON'T TASTE GOOD AT EAGLE
author: Ryan H.

description: Yesterday a service man from SF Fleet Week assaulted me with a whip while trying to sing karaoke at the SF Eagle and no one stopped him! I told him multiple times to stop but he continued to whip me 4-5 times with a toy another patron leant to him. I even told him no into the mic and no one from staff or in the crowd stopped him. I even ended my song early because I was so upset and still no one from staff said a thing. The best I got was an apology after being yelled at by the bar tender after scolding him about what happened. I now have unwanted marks on my back. #consentviolation #iguessitisokaytoassaulttranswomen #whereismybdsmcommunity #dontfeelsafe
author: Violet M.

description: It's just a bar, being from nyc and always hearing about the San Fran location, it's really just a open air bar, community- bs; fetish-bs, it's just a bar nothing to be excited about; it's like margaritavill of boring
author: MK M.

description:
Don't judge.

This club has been around since the 70's and we've all heard of it. Maybe our thoughts and discussions revolved around the dark and filthy nature of what happens behind these closed doors but the reality is, it's pretty damn cool.

Walk in and find yourself inside a dark bar with gazing eyes all around and perhaps a dancer or two. But who doesn't enjoy a stuffed banana hammock everyone once in a while? Grab a decently made drink at the bar and make your way outside. This is where the magic happens.

Step outside and all of a sudden you're transported into a world that could only excite my child-like giddiness for memories of laser tag and leather. Tom of Finland abound and the crowd all made after his likeness. Some people have died and gone to gay heaven... maybe even perhaps, moi.
author: Kevin J.

description: Went there during SF pride week. Nice big place with a great patio. Friendly staff. Multiple bars so I didn't have to wait in a line for a drink. Will be back for sure!
author: David M.

description:
This is a pretty comfortable environment.
I like the stage and the outside patio.
The liquor is good here, great prices.
They make the drinks very well.

Every wednesday is open mic with Kollin Holtz.

Its a comfortable setting. 
He's very chill.
The comics are very encouraging here too.

Open mic starts at 6pm.

Its a great location and perfect time .
author: Luke S.

description: In all of SF, the most diverse, friendly, welcoming crowd. There's someone for everyone here, regardless of the theme/event or lack thereof. Great friendly bartenders pouring great drinks. Love this place! Nice diversion from the Castro crowd.
author: Richard V.

description:
Long time San Franciscans Mike and Eduardo (sorry about not mentioning all the others who worked on this) took the run-down also ran bar and turned it into an amazing place.  I love Bruce and Charlie, the guys  down the street who are working hard to bring back their watering hole to it's glory days, 
Right now, the Eagle is the place.  For the  complainer about a watered down IPA, I drink it too and found it very typical and satisfying.
author: Ron W.

description: Ok.  So I shouldn't fault the Eagle for the lack of friendliness of the clientele.  But it was SO cliquish it was ridiculous.  Visiting San Francisco from Dallas.  Saturday night was beyond packed.  But not much fun.  Lots of cute guys and I'm not ugly.  But it was the stand and pose mentality.  So thought I'd check it out Sunday afternoon.  Packed again but again the crowd couldn't be more rude.  And people plow you down like you're not even there.  So, because I'm a gluten for punishment, I checked it out Monday night.  Dead.  But I stayed for two overpriced weak drinks.  Obviously not the place to go on a Monday.  I thought about buying a t-shirt.  Then I thought "Why bother?!"   It just wasn't conducive for fun.
author: Michael K.

description: This bar advertises a monthly karaoke contest that they claim is open to all contestants. Don't fall for it. Unless you are gay and under 40, you are not welcome there, and they will make it pretty uncomfortable for you in the process of sending the unspoken signals.
author: Lynn F.

description:
Put your best foot forward, they always say. Well, sadly, Mike has put that foot in his mouth by hiring an amazingly rude doorman. 
 I didn't get his name, but he's on the tall side with curly hair and beard. Look for the guy hassling, taunting, and insulting hearing-impaired people. Calling someone a little bitch because they can't hear you is uncalled for in any situation and probably illegal.
author: Steve G.

description: Friendly staff but unfriendly, closed-off crowd. I went three times as a visitor from out of town and felt like a pariah. They also love to shake down patrons with an expensive cover charge. Go to lone star or hole in the wall instead.
author: L L.

description: How does this place even stay in business?  Went on a Saturday night, paid a ridiculous cover and the bar was empty...at 12:30am, with the exception of three glamor-cubs, you know, guys who have beards but wear glitter lipstick and fill their beards with glitter and then wear high heels.  What the hell happened to this place?  Wow....just wow.
author: Russ S.

description: A bar that stands out above the rest with an attitude and environment you have to see , always something fun going on
author: John W.

description: If your thing is douchey, obnoxious security look no further.  Hank - 6' 6" beanpole security guy - is disrespectful, antagonistic, and sarcastic to patrons.  These observations were made over multiple visits.  A business that does not value their customers will not be in business for long.  If you want a more pleasant experience suggest trying the Powerhouse.
author: Robert G.

description:
It's an important stop on the leather bar scene. Recently reopened.Came here on a Thursday and Saturday. Saturday was more happening. The service is SO friendly! I loved it. Soccer matches on at the bar. A back room for trysts is separate from gender neutral ones on the other side which is convenient. Great back patio.

Overall, very friendly, sexy crowd that felt like home... But way hotter. Check out the art!
author: Peter S.

description:
Fun and great bar with a super awesome bartender..!!!! The music was great too
Love their massive outdoor place..!
author: Maki J.

description:
Gorgeous huge patio that soaks up the sunlight during summer months, but even in January, the heat lamps and the giant barbecue beneath the stage keeps things toasty.

Three different bars keep everyone well-lubricated and the crowd is a mix of daddies, leather folks, and assorted neighborinos, with everyone tending towards older and whiter.

Limited beer selection.
author: Kevin L.

description:
First time back here since the new owners. I have to see it's much improved. They seemed to open things up, clean things up, get rid of the crap taking up space, and really make it more inviting. 

The Sunday crowd was really inviting. Staff was friendly and welcoming. Plus, it was quite so packed, so one could walk around for a change. The deck, in particular, was more conducive to people. 

There were some women making turkey burgers (??) by the grill. They did not look appealing at all!! (Take a lesson from the guys who make the AMAZGING hamburgers at The Hole in San Diego on Sunday's Beer Bust. Then you're have a REAL burger!)

Only complaint (like last time) was the smokers/smoking EVERYWEHRE!!! There was little escaping it. It would be so nice to have the smokers in one section so the non-smokers don't have to deal with it. 

I "get it" that it's a liberal, leather bar, but that does not change the fact that some of use are health-conscious.

Overall, Nicely done SF Eagle.
author: Bill R.

description:
Not sure what people expect when you head to the eagle.   But fantastic place to go for a beer on Sunday afternoon.    You'll not find it likes a pretty place. It's can be dirty and not the pretty place that some folks thinks it's going to be.   
But he'll a fun place. People are cool.   Overall. Best time. Sunday afternoon
author: J A.

description:
Hey it's nice to be in a GAY bar where guys aren't bringing their fag hags and hetero friends, hardly anything is gay sacred in SF anymore. Crowd is friendly, good variety of beers on tap and SUN on the patio! None of the pretentiousness the Midnite Sun can have whew!
GAY GAY GAY THANK YOU PLEASE STAY THAT WAY
author: Risque B.

description:
I was here for a special event, the Be-Robin-A-Thon, a charity function to raise money and awareness for the homeless. While I did not bring anything to donate, I threw whatever cash I could into the donation box, a nice handful of crisp dollar bills. I made it rain like only a poor girl can. 

While it wasn't the most packed event I've ever been to, there were a reasonably large number of people crammed into a tiny space by the inside stage. A lot of pushing and shoving and no "excuse me"s. The outside stage was even worse. It's sort of like an outdoor patio courtyard type of place. Everyone was smoking! Cigarettes, cigars, and uh.... wacky tobaccy, too. I'm not against people using recreational marijuana, but at a bar? That's pushing it. 

Many of the bigger, taller men muscled their way to the front to get a better view. I'm about 5'10", so it didn't bother me that much, but my friend is closer to 5" tall and couldn't see anything. They didn't seem to show any remorse. I've gotten better about asking tinier folk if they want to stand in front of me. Everyone deserves a chance to see the stage. 

I didn't like that there was only one bathroom stall (unless there is a secret second restroom hidden somewhere else). Waiting in line to use the restroom, especially a few drinks into the night, is pretty unpleasant. I've never peed my pants yet, but there have been a few close calls. Ha, talk about TMI Tuesday. 

Despite the imperfect atmosphere, I met Margaret Cho. She was lovely. A little bit drunk and very busy. We didn't really get a chance to talk at all (she was constantly swarmed with friends, fans, performers, etc) but she let me take a quick photo with her before she swooped off into the night.
author: Brandi W.

description:
One of my friends got me to start frequenting this place. They have a large space, and they're almost always rolling out new events. I usually encounter the events by chance more than planning, but they're happy coincidences nonetheless with plenty of eye candy. 

Their patio is heated as well as host to SF's largest beer bust weekly. If you get into the beer bust, don't leave, you might not be able to get back in. It's a maximum occupancy thing, and I get why they have to do it, but it sucks anyway. However, they won't sell you food unless you buy a beer cup, in spite the fact I'm making them more money paying full price for my cocktails, 

The bouncers are also pretty friendly. Though, one gripe they have control of was charging me to get back in when I went and grabbed food. Most bars won't charge you to get back in if you just step out, but I was, which was a little lame.
author: dAvid s.

description:
When I moved to San Francisco several years ago, I thought of the bars, "Ugh. Look at all these cramped spaces. Dingy, dirty decor. Filthy bathrooms." And in gay bars, "Ugh, *another* pee trough? Do I have to be on display every time I need to piss?"

Now it feels like, in places like SF Eagle, some bars are too big. I come here often on video game nights, a Tuesday event where video games are put on big TVs and projection screens. Lots of people come out for it, especially on a Tuesday, but the bar is just too spacious to socialize. Other bars like Hi Tops have this problem, too: basically people stick around little clumps of friends and interact that way, instead of, say, in Mix, where there's just enough room on the patio for you not to fall into the arms of the person next to you. In that way, you end up talking to half the people there.

Which isn't to say this is a bad bar. The bartenders are really nice peeps, and they look understaffed, so props to them for dealing with us. My favorite is this daddy bartender who is extra patient when I make up drinks for him to invent on video game night. Thus far, I've tried:

~ "Power Up"
~ "Rainbow Road"
~ "Turbo"
~ "Donkey Kong Country"

... and a "Princess Peach," but apparently, that one was just a Sex on the Beach.
author: David S.

description:
One of the few smoker-friendly bars left. It's a shame there aren't more places left where you can enjoy a cigarette in the open air... 
Without the burden of having your airspace invaded by a devolving asthma victim as they try to muster up their gag reflex enough to remember to cover their mouth when they cough in your general direction.
Great mixed crowd and here to stay.
author: Sterling F.

description:
Went during a Sunday beer bust, was amazing. I also ended up here after the the Folsom fair, was amazing. I love bikers and daddies, this was a heaven for me! Gotta come back soon.

The bartenders and door guys were all very nice. They have a good selection of alcohol, limited restroom indoors. The outside men's urinal was kind of stinky. The patio is an amazing place to be during summer!
author: Sunny E.

description:
I would give the Eagle 5 stars if it weren't for the cigarettes everywhere!!  Cigarettes, cigarettes everywhere!!  There is no way to get away from it unless you go inside ... and if you know The Eagle, why would you want to be inside.  Especially on a Sunday Beer Bust day.  

I've been a patron of this bar for over 20 years and have had some amazing Sundays here.  And I was incredibly happy when it reopened after being closed for over a year.  But lately the smoking outside has become absolutely unbearable.  The attitude here is that if you don't like breathing cigarette smoke, then you should just leave.  

This is a really sad reality.  Especially 50 years after the Surgeon General said that smoking causes lung disease and it's now well known that 2nd hand smoke is dangerous.  

Smokers here will light up and blow smoke in your face and nearly burn you with their lit cigarette and it doesn't matter where you try to take refuge.  Heck, I've actually been burned by their cigarettes being carelessly waved around.  Even if you're in the more covered parts of the bar, like the pergola style cover, where the airspace is even more confined. 

 I've also seen people light up INSIDE at the back bar, which is an INDOOR space just off the back patio.  And no one says anything.  But if you're someone, like me (and my friends), who doesn't wish to breath their smoke... well, then it's just up to you to find some place else to stand.

The management of this bar doesn't care because they are all smokers and want to be able to smoke anywhere.  It's really sad for those of us who are not addicted to tobacco.  Because there is no place for us to enjoy ourselves on a sunny Sunday afternoon, except for the dark, mostly empty interior of the front bar.

I would like to see the management set up the UPPER back patio area as a smoking area and not allow people to smoke elsewhere.  Or at the very least not allow people to smoke under the pergola, since the airspace is so confined under there that it's almost like an indoor space.

Now for the reasons I give this bar 4 stars.  Great place to hang out with your friends on a Sunday afternoon.  Well priced drinks and friendly sexy bartenders.  A really amazingly diverse crowd of hot men and complete freaks.  A very nicely done space too.  A lot of history here as one of San Francisco great Bohemian and Leather Gay Sunday Beer Bust spaces.  I hope it stays around forever!!
author: Daniel S.

description: Want to like the Eagle as an old time stalwart.  Went on Monday.  Overcharged me $8 for a "happy hour" beer.  No refund.  Just.  "Oh, sorry".  Won't be back.  Sad clientele and staff.
author: Glenneagleson ..

description: This has been pretty much a landmark bar among the gay community for the last few decades but in the last two or three years it's going quickly downhill.  The crowd is almost all 20-something bears and they're rude and act like they own the place.  If you're into the bear culture, great, but there are others in the gay community that don't think gaining 250 pounds is a particularly healthy lifestyle.  To the owners: how about showing some awareness that there are other types of gay men in S.F.?
author: Doug M.

description:
Location : good spot ( hard to catch a cab when leaving)

Venue: fantastic what they have done with the place. Changed the bar inside great job!

Smoking: should be only in one section of the patio as not everyone smokes. This day and age smoking cigars or cigarettes  should not be allowed at all in bars. It turns peoples stomachs. 

Door guys: super friendly

Bartenders: this is where things go bad. The bartenders are the worst. Super rude and slow. 

One huge thing that turned me off was a "manager guy" (bigger guy) was walking to the back employee area on the patio and was forcing himself through the crowd even though there was plenty of room. He was pushing people out of the way. This was so unprofessional. I am so sad to see this rude behavior in a bar. I know it gets crowded but there is a way of working your self through the crowd. This is a huge reason I will not be back anytime soon. He did this twice that I saw and was pushed once. 

This place has huge potential but on a bad path.
author: Matthew F.

description: Ok the most disgusting bar. Came here for a fun night, I saw people being tortured, the bartender Asked if we were having shots, told him I wanted two Washington Apples, he said he wanted shots he didn't have to shake. If they are too lazy to pour a decent shot, they shouldn't be open.
author: Omar A.

description:
There are two functions for the SF Eagle: Gay bar and rock show venue.  This review is for the ladder.  Came here to see Thee Oh Sees and Total Control last night.  A sign on their door stated the club's doors would open at 7:30 and they didn't actually open up until 8:00.  They hire douchey security to patrol out front.  One of the little Napoleonic guards was taking people's tallboys away and trashing them while they waited in line for doors to open.  

The staff inside the bar (not the security force, mind you) is pretty friendly and attentive.  We went up to the bar multiple times and never waited more than 30 seconds for a drink.  The patio is has heat lamps and was even set up with a bootblack station where a guy in assless leather chaps was shining away boots.

At one point I wanted to leave briefly for a pack of smokes and come back, so I asked the staff inside the doorway if that would be okay.  No problem at all, they said. But then the security guards outside said we would have to wait in the massive line again.  Really?  Because I did, after all, pay $15 for this show and am wearing my wristband.  

Also, show was way overpacked.
author: Eric F.

description:
THE EAGLE IS BACK!!!!!

It's true folks, I was there last night, drank with people at their fabulously made over space! 
furnishings are all the same, they kept the old bar, layout has changed a little with the bar off to the side now instead of in the middle, and now they have COLD DRAFT BEER!!! and a lot of good choices! 

new roof, fresh paint, lots of work went into this renovation, and the people are going to love it! 

I thought for sure the place was gone and was going to be turned into some restaurant, but no, the whole gang is back, and it looks really good. 

Time to party at the Eagle again!!!!!
author: Adrian M.

description:
I am not writing my own review, beyond saying this place rocks, and just want to point out the kind of people who are giving fewer than 5 stars:

"I suppose I wasn't fully prepared for the fetishes I saw in full effect on what I  thought would be a mild Tuesday night...but what prepares you for reapeated random animalistic, sexual grunting and growling, a 60 y.o. man's junk out for the world to "enjoy" and man kneels rubbing his dong while another man steps on his face. 

I wasn't ready."

If you're this kind of person, best to avoid. The rest of you, get ready to have a bearlicious leathery time, even if you're a straight woman like me =D
author: Diabla T.

description: Last night was my first night back to the Eagle since it reopened. There aren't many bars in San Francisco where so many different ages and types of people mix so naturally. Live music on Thursday nights. I never get tired of Pansy Division.
author: Brian D.

description: Great nights at The Eagle.  No seating to speak of and crowds were HUGE.  However, drinks were good if pricey, and the crowd was varied and fun.  Great staff, too, and music at a level that could be heard easily but didn't drown out the conversations.  I went the night before Folsom and the night of. The night before was much, much lighter and the visit more enjoyable.  I'd definitely visit again and it's worth standing in line just to get Gage to make your drinks!
author: Cyn D.

description:
Great location, great people, very nice service .. 

I loved the place .. definitely won't forget Lone Star for that .. 

I guess I'll go back and forth to both .. :-D
author: Nicolas D.

description: I been going to the eagle and other gay bars in SF for ten years and have never had any problems. A while ago I was in the restroom and this guy tried to reach over to grab me and I told him I wasn't interested and he continued after I asked him nicely. Then I told him to f#$k off and left the bar. The next time I went in one of the owners (Mike) pulled me to the side and told me he got multiple complaints about me from the last time I was here and said I was intoxicated which I wasn't because I live in Sacramento and do not drink and drive and only came up for a day trip that day. He threatened to kick me out if he gets anymore complaints and I didn't even remember what he was talking about since I rarely come here because I live in Sacramento. Didn't even give me a chance to think and tell my side of the story. From this day on the big heftier owner(not Mike) would give me dirty looks every time he would see me. One day one of my friends smoked him out and my friend introduced us not knowing that he didn't like me and he was very rude and gave me a dirty look. I brushed it off.. I came back Folsom weekend and the heftier owner was intoxicated and was harassing me the whole time I was there. He said "didn't I kick you out 5 times already?" Then he said "leave now" but I didn't since I was there hanging with my friends/ my ride home. He continued to walk by giving me dirty looks so I just left to the lonestar where my business is appreciated and I just let my ride know. Last time I'll ever go to the SF eagle. Never had any problems at any bars in SF until these guys took over the eagle.
author: Neftali G.

description: Sunday Beer Bust is a MUST experience for Gay/Homosexual Men in San Francisco...Hours between 3 pm and 6 pm
author: Christian Olsen S.

description:
They kept the feel of the old place while bringing it up to current building codes.  That could not have been easy.  The line to get in is long because everyone wants to check out the new place and they don't want any problems with overcrowding, but once you get in, it is like old times.

Congrats to the new owners.
author: Bay G.

description: It just goes to show what happens when I have both a Saturday & Sunday free, ( a rarity due to my line of work), I end up at The Eagle.  On a chilly, Saturday night, I attend UBeard, complete with fabulous Christmas lights, Dos Equis, on tap and fetching go-go boys.  Sunday, afternoon, I attended the "Faerie Beer Bust" (my first Sunday, Eagle, beer bust in 10 years), and have a great time, with all sorts of guys, comfortable in their own skin.  Although, The Eagle has gone through changes since it's closure and re-opening, it continues to be an accepting place for all.
author: Carlos C.

description: I would like to start by saying that my first encounters with this bar and its 2 managing partners/owners,  Lex and Mike, were pleasant. The nature of our acquaintanceship is purely business and was always cordial, which is why when Lex and Mike were in a bind and needed to "borrow" money from me, I had no problem fronting it to them with the agreement that they would pay me back as they were reimbursed in increments with free product from the company I worked for. I left the company late last year but couldn't collect from Lex and Mike as they hadn't yet been reimbursed with free product. I informed them of my departure and they agreed to stay in touch until the repayment to me was resolved. We finally met in March of this year. Mike insisted he paid me half the owed amount in December before I left. That's where the problem started. They gave me half via check that day in early March and continued to press that they gave me a Visa gift card in December 2015 before I left for another job opportunity. Interesting thing is though, Mike's excel ledger that he records all business transactions in, was conveniently corrupted. Lex and Mike are pretty great actors as they tried in front of me for about 20 minutes to "open" a file that turned out to be "corrupted." I've asked them to check on their end to see where the card they're claiming they gave me was spent. They said they'd look into it......now they're just ignoring me. Truly, this wouldn't bother me as much if I wasn't a single mother raising a 17-month old son with bills to pay. But I'm trying to pay off medical bills from when my son and i didn't have insurance in the later part of my maternity leave. Why am I writing this? I want the people who frequent this bar to know that the owners are the type of people that will take advantage of good people without a second thought even though, given the popularity of Eagle, they are pulling in money hand over fist most nights, if not all.
author: Dominique L.

description: So, the idea is lovely and fun and sexy but the staff is rude and pompous. They told us that we had to move away from the bar because we had finished our drinks and weren't allowed to stand there without new drinks. Umm...what?! Don't got here. These people suck.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I frikkin love this place. I'm no leather biker daddy but it's such a nice large open space with a massive outdoor patio The staff are always friendly and the clientele are not snooty.
author: Shawn C.

description: love the sf leather secene bar im a fan i might come back
author: Leigh G.

description: Not only is the staff great, I left an item there this past weekend with my ID, debit card and phone inside.  The staff ensured that it was collected and made available for me to pickup on Monday.  Thank you to the eagle staff for being considerate and conscious!
author: Forrest B.

description: The SF Eagle has reopened!  Kudos to the new owners and GM Ron Hennis -- amazing job, some changes, moving the Eagle into the future.  Great selection of new employees, diverse, fresh, and very customer service oriented.  This bar has a great new feel -- but with some touches of the past.  It's not just Sunday Beer Bust -- it's not just Thursday night band night -- happy hour, weekend nights (new monthly parties!!!), and weekday nights are a great time to try out this new bar!
author: David M.

description: Missed you old friend. Yeah yeah yeah, there are changes but knowing how it could have turned out i think they did a great job of keeping it old school yet improving where needed. Nice staff and as always a party every night.
author: Jorge E.

description:
When my friend suggested that my wife and I go to see a show near where I work, I thought "Why not"?

After visiting the SF eagle's website I did manage to speculate on a few very good reasons why not and I am really glad that we ended up going. 

The place is a biker bar (you get happy hour prices if you have a motorcycle helmet) and there is more than just a hint of lavender about the place.

"Is this a gay bar?" the missus innocently enquired as we darkened its door.  "I don't think so, my mate didn't mention......." I replied just as we both enter to be confronted with one gentleman groping the other's arse as when ambled over to the bar.  Without breaking stride we order our drinks and wander out to the patio.  The missus was the only girl.  Not only that but the vast majority of gents present were now looking in our direction and I swear the amount of facial hair on show could have insulated a small maisonette. 

With 30 seconds a huge man with flowing a flowing ginger beard introduced himself as 'Tank' and after that we were treated like honoured guests and had a great night. 

Shout out to Roman and 'The Big Bear' and also met Gary Floyd out of The Dicks.  Great place.  We went several times after that.  Amazing variety of people there.  Great bands too.  NOFX went there after their show.  You can hear them on their 2nd live album saying "See y'all at The Eagle", by the way.

There was an incident at The Bear Festival which will remain a secret.......
author: nottellinya a.

description: I guess it reopened ... Good mix, nice space & the out door patio was EXCELLENT!
author: Grant S.

description:
Okay, I'm not a gay man, I'm not into leather daddies/queens/bears, et al--much less, men--but I know a good bar when I see it.

Gay bars... straight bars... douchebag bars... dive bars... No matter what other incompatibilities exist, the commonality here is "bar." Alcohol. It's what brings people together.

At the Eagle, it brings together...

Alright, I'm not the target demographic. But, for those who are, this is a great spot. I think it'd be a nice place to hang out and have some after work drinks with a friend, too. Irrespective of the overt niche subscription displayed at the Eagle, the crowd is friendly, the bartender was capable and chummy, and the patio is expansive and filled with places to sit in and out of the sun and isn't full of tools and douchebags (i.e., Zeitgeist, the increasingly past-its-prime shithole of hipster present).

Your girlfriends aren't going to like the missing doors on the stalls, tho.
author: Martin W.

description: Saw Thee Oh Sees there   last night and it was a blast.. Minor point, given how hot and crowed it was, some  persons should have used  deodorants, but that is certainly not the fault of the venue. Perhaps in addition to checking IDs at the door, they should check for deodorant.
author: Adam G.

description:
So, I love dive bar. But really? I mean, I suppose I wasn't fully prepared for the fetishes I saw in full effect on what I  thought would be a mild Tuesday night. That is possible. But what prepares you for reapeated random animalistic, sexual grunting and growling, a 60 y.o. man's junk out for the world to "enjoy" and man kneels rubbing his dong while another man steps on his face. 

I wasn't ready.
author: Chia C.

description:
Please join the Milk Club and email these supervisors and mayor.

Use our words or your own. Tell our electeds why this IS OUR SPACE!

MILK CLUB LETTER ON THE EAGLE CLUB'S SALE
It has recently come to our attention that a non-LGBT group of entrepreneurs has entered into a purchase agreement for the former Eagle Tavern. This comes as a shock to many in the LGBT community as there was no outreach done or notice given about this historical community space despite the fact that many LGBT San Franciscans had expressed much interest in the building's future. Furthermore our community had previously heard that there were queer entrepreneurs in negotiation to take over this space; buyers who intended to return it to a place that would continue to serve as a center to those who previously patronized the Eagle and enjoyed it as a LGBT-friendly space.
This startling change of course has caused great concern within those of us who considered the Eagle as a haven and who still view it as a revered symbol of San Francisco's continued struggle with the HIV/AIDS epidemic and a critical meeting site for the marginalized queer community. To our dismay, such spaces are becoming scarcer, and our marginalization is becoming more profound. The Eagle is more than a bar and a business, yet current city processes appear to regard it as just another tavern. The Eagle is hallowed ground for us, and we as stakeholders must participate in any decisions about its future through a vigorous community-wide dialogue where all voices can be heard.
We offer here several specific reasons why we consider the Eagle to be a sacred space. They are given so that you can understand and respect our alarm at these developments:

*The ashes of gay men and women who died during the AIDS epidemic are scattered there.
*The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence have blessed it as hallowed queer space and have used it to veil many postulants.
*Over its 30 year history over $50 million was raised for charities, particularly HIV/AIDS organizations.
**It was a place that was accessible to the full spectrum of diversity of the LGBT community.
It was our community center.

Given the historical, cultural, and emotional significance of this site we find it just to demand a process where all members of the queer community have an opportunity to participate in decisions regarding its future. We demand that an open meeting be held at the earliest possible date and ask that our elected officials, community representatives, the general public, and all key parties be in attendance. We also believe that the Eagle must be given Historic Landmark status.
South of Market is undergoing a massive shift in its composition and it is important to allow members of the community to speak for themselves before rash decisions about its future are made. We look forward to this discussion.

Your name here!

Jane.Kim@sfgov.org (D6 home of the Eagle)
Scott.Weiner@sfgov.org (D8)
Christina.Olague@sfgov.org (D5 and head of committee reg. liquor license transfer)
David.Chiu@sfgo.org (D3 President of the BOS)
David.Campos@sfgov.org (D9)
John.Avalos@sfgov.org (D11)
Sean.Elsbernd@sfgov.org (D7 on committee for liquor license transfer)
Carmen.Chu@sfgov.org (D4)
Mark.Farrell@sfgov.org (D2)
Malia.Cohen@sfgov.org (D10)
Eric.L.Mar@sfgov.org (D1)
Ed.Lee@sfgov.org (Mayor)
author: Anna C.

description:
I always enjoy myself when I stop in for a beer.  Beer busts on Sundays are a must do and it's a friendly crowd.  I've never had to pay a cover so a previous reviewer must have gone on a concert night.  

I have had occasional poor experiences with some slow bartenders who find it more important to talk to friends then to help someone standing at the service station... so I just avoid them and give my tips to someone else.
author: Bill L.

description: So glad it has reopened. The new owners have done a GREAT job at the place. I LOVE that you don't have to wait in long lines for a beer anymore! It is being back "home"... yet much better now.
author: Travis L.

description: The new and improved Eagle is back and in full swing! This place has been redone amazingly well.  The bar staff is extremely fast and friendly and efficient and very pleasant to look at.  The outdoor area is to die for and there are outdoor heaters that cover pretty much the entire outdoor spread which is unbelievably nice during the colder evenings.  There are at least 3 bar stations in this place from my own count and each one of them is manned by gorgeous friendly bartenders that actually take the time to talk and have a good time while they work.  I'm not a huge fan of the semi-sleazy mirrored piss troughs, but it is what it is being the Eagle and all.  Will definitely be coming back here with my partner and friends.
author: Adam K.

description: NOT CLOSED ANYMORE. Reopened March 3, 2013 to general acclaim and tumult. Let the good times roll again!
author: Taylor J.

description: Fun times!  The door girl is the best!!!  She was both welcoming and "just one of the guys".  Jeff is a great bartender!
author: Patrick M.

description:
Thursday Night Live is a San Francisco establishment!  I cringe at the thought of living in this city without it, so please patron this bar and give them shit tons of money!  

The beer bust is really good on Sundays, but it can get a bit crowded.  No shortage of sexy, hairy gay dudes though.  Actually for that matter no shortage of sexy lesbians in leather either!  

The bartending staff are really great guys, especially Doug and TastyCakes!
author: james r.

description:
My favorite bar for a day out.  Be seen and see something great at The Eagle Tavern!

This place is great - a real bar.  No prudes here - this is like where "Guys Gone Wild" must have been filmed.  

Beer Bust on Sunday is when we go because the patio (no matter how bad the weather) is always where to be.  Unlimited Miller Hi-Life starting at 3 and goes til like 7...  Gets real packed around 6:30.

And this is where the hot guys hang.  Not so hot guys hang at the LAMESTAR!
author: James V.

description: Pretty fun bar. I like the beer bust on Sundays. Staff is generally pretty nice even if a little slow sometimes.
author: Brendan W.

description:
Please don't go! "SHANE! DON"T GO!" This place is the bomb! If you don't know why then go! Support this place and convince them to not close. This is history.

I just wanted to add that when I was surrounded by 4 cop cars on Folsom and interrogated by 8 cops, for an hour, this was the best place to go, afterwards, to relax and unwind. This is a simple place of simple pleasures in a bar.
author: Joe P.

description:
This place has mega potential to be an all round great bar. I went on a party night on May 17th, I have to say the DJ was terrible, and was in the middle of a stage (which could be used for a dance floor). If your going to have a dj, make it where they can dance (move into the booth!) since the stage area has lights and a disco ball. If you want to mix up the music, mix it up on the patio or back bar. That way if people dont want to listen to house/or mainstream remix they can go to the patio and back bar and listen to other forms of music and just chat!
The staff, was very friendly (which is a plus!) and the crowd was a good mix of young and old (leather, and non leather). So for now good place for a drink and people watch but that is about it.
author: Justin B.

description: Had two bad experiences here. The first time the bar tender thought a yager bomb was rockstar and a shot of yager over the rockks. The second was a vodka soda wound up being club soda with lime. Atmosphere is ok but you must babysit the bartenders.
author: Jesse G.

description:
This review is only for Thursday Nite Live because I've never been to the glorious Eagle Tavern any other night besides. My verdict is that Thursday Nite Live is one of the best music nights around the Bay Area.

Even though after this past Thursday I don't really wanna write anything because there were SO MANY FREAKING PEOPLE THERE it was hard to move, get a drink, find friends, hear yourself talk, etc. I've never seen so many people at the Eagle Tavern which is, I guess, good for the spot's cred and longevity, but it also seemed to be contaminated by more than it's share of douches (of which they are usually a negligible amount) this particular Thursday. Even the outside patio, usually a spacious respite from the microscopic inner bar, felt like a can of sardines. Really, really good looking sardines.

ANYWAY, onto the music--Bay Area gems like Thee Oh Sees, the Fresh & Onlys, Mayyors, etc. etc. etc. play here on the regular and give SPECTACULAR shows--there's something about the totally cramped, weirdly shaped audience area that just sends people into hysterics and it makes it hard not to get caught up in everyone else's energy. Plus, drinks are cheap and the staff is friendly. It all makes for late, awesome nights that remind you why it rules to be young.
author: Laura M.

description:
Thank you to the kind bartender for dealing with a slightly tipsy Pup!

I was disheartened upon walking into The Eagle Tavern.  When I frequent the Eagle in Los Angeles, the place is pretty busy and exciting!  What I walked into was what seemed to be a dead night.  Really?  Dead on a Saturday Night?  I surveyed the place, comparing it to the Eagle LA and browsing the locals.  A few comments and calls towards me lifted my spirits to let me know this place was alive!  Yes...this dawg was without a chain...maybe next time, you'll grab a leash and -- Oh wait...back to the review!

The music was decent, though I didn't notice a DJ unless I wasn't looking hard enough.  I was told I missed an event earlier in the day and optimistically hope to find busier days!  Overall, I find the dark atmosphere to be very alluring.  I did see some very attractive guys roaming the corners, though being the pup I am...must wait to be approached.  

The patio is probably what made me the happiest.  It was VERY sizeable and relaxing!  This was the spot of choice for me to enjoy my (excessively strong) drink.  I will admit, the drink was still tasty, AND it was 2.50 less than down the street at the Stud Bar where another event was going on.  I thought the drink being served in a mason mug was a nice touch.  I look forward to returning on a busier night with mischief in mind!

Sadly, I am not local to San Francisco, so my visits will be monthly at best.  If the events are anything like the Eagle LA, I will be a super happy pup!

Optimistically barking up the right tree...

~ A Stray Dawg
author: Tk C.

description:
The patio is awesome. There's enough space to get away from the crowd but there's plenty of opportunities to mingle with the leather daddies and bears if you so desire.The entire bar is done in a motorcycle / woodlands theme that feels cozy or dirty, which ever you prefer. 

The toilet is a trough that 3 guys can squeeze into if the mood is right. I'm sure there's a proper toilet somewhere, but I've never seen it. 

Personally, I'd like to see more real bikers at the bar. I rarely see any Harleys parked out front, but still all the men are dressed in Harley tees and leather gear. I assume they are bike lovers but decided a Prius would be more practical. On second thought, drinking and bike riding probably isn't a good combination, so perhaps they are smart by not riding their bikes to the bar.

The last time I was there, the music was far out, old trippy rock n roll that was way too mellow for such a rambunctious crowd. Maybe it was a special night for old stoners that I wasn't aware of. I hope that the next time I'm out there, the music in modern rock and up beat.

I'll update this soon, I need to go back for another round.
author: Rex D.

description: This place has gone downhill since the new owners took over.  What's the deal with the constant cover charges?  I remember going a few saturdays ago and it was 8 bucks to get in and so I left and came back not more than 10 minutes later and the troll at the the door tried to charge me 10 bucks.  Really?  How shady can you get?
author: D. D.

description:
I just heard the most amazing DJ set here. Chiffons, Melvins, new Prince, "Leader of the Pack", Queens of the Stone Age, AC/DC. Everything flowed together effortlessly. The music here (and at Hole in the Wall) can't be underrated. And the sound system is pristine. 

A good place to go to forget about the rest of the world.
author: Martin Q.

description:
This place has THE BEST patio to get your drink on with the accompanying cigarette.

I only come to this place on Sundays, for their $10 beer bust and every Sunday that I come is ALWAYS a great time.

If you don't like older gay men in drones wearing leather accessories (and sometimes wearing almost nothing!), then don't come here. The big burly gay bears run this joint, so if you don't like it...head to Castro.

I'm on open minded chap, so I deal. I love it.
author: Trav M.

description:
One of my favorite places to hang out on Sunday.

How can you go wrong, $10 beer bust, hot men, great patio, and food. (I never eat it but a lot of peeps do).

Yay!
author: Fred R.

description: One of my favorite places in SF!!!! Im a fag hag and I love me some bears and leather daddies!!! Beer bust sunday funday!!! I would always go in with Roman and Tank and have the best time!!! This is Rome, hi everyone!!! Amazing!! I love the mixed crowd, not afraid to let the straight people in, or lesbians, or freak drag queens. A good friendly mix, i love this place!!!!
author: R. S.

description:
So tempted to give this a one star review to try to keep all the lousy hipster dudes out, but then I remembered that the Eagle has its own natural defense that other contenders for best outdoor beer patio lacked (sorry Zeitgeist, truly I am) ...and that is: BIG BEARDED GAY BEARS ALMOST LITERALLY CRAWLING OUT OF THE WOODWORK. Seriously, hipsters, don't even bother. It's going to be hard putting the Chrome bag and ironic t-shirt to work scoring your indie chicks when you can't walk 5 feet at the Eagle without a penis with what looks like a Hell's Angel from Alabama attached to the other end of it practically falling into your mouth. There are mirrors on the urinal positioned so your neighbors can check out your dangling sea otter! Stay away, it's better for everyone involved.

Best legal venue in the city to see the Extra Action Marching Band.
author: Dav Y.

description:
where else can you drink with homeless people, trannies, punks, pretty boys and leather queens in a dive bar setting with cheap beer and free food?  (Yes I'm speaking about Sundays...)  I luff this place

Other nights/days it's relatively calm and quiet...
author: Matt V.

description:
save the eagle tavern!!  i've seen such great shows at this venue, grizzly bear, holy shit, erase errata!!               please never close  :(

http://www.thebaybridged.com/2011/04/11/eagle-tavern-set-to-close-april-29th-community-meeting-tonight-to-save-the-venue/
author: Noel J.

description:
It's possible to become a bitter old hag at the age of 26. Hell, I was a bitter old hag at the age of 18, so it's no surprise, as life continually beats you into submission, that it only gets worse with each passing year (or hour, minute, second, etc). As my high school guidance counselor used to tell me, "life sucks and people are shit" (RIP Mr. Kirson). 

Anyway, when life beats you down YET AGAIN and you are not granted access to the Halloween party of your choice, it was nice to come to the Eagle, a breath of fresh, leathery, cradle of filth listening, my name is ash and i am a slave watching, air where they will pump you full of jack daniel's, give you a bathroom without a lock (just get over yourself and piss) and remind you that life is beautiful and is indeed worth living.
author: Maria D.

description:
The first time I ever set foot in the Eagle Tavern was with Nadja M. and her then-boyfriend, about two years ago. It was the memorable night of "these cheaps are drink!" fame, and the kickass bartender who looked like Sammy Hagar, and the gay porn, and oh, the good times...

A year later, my would-be SuperBF stumbled in there looking for an ATM on the way to our first booty call (yes, you read that right). He found the ATM, and he also discovered that the Eagle Tavern, though filled with gay men who might be checking him out in a manly-gay-man kind of way, looked like a really cool place to hang out. IF HE DIDN'T HAVE A GIRL TO GO HOOK UP WITH. THAT'S RIGHT. A GIRL.

A year later, SuperBF and I found ourselves back there, at a fundraiser for Dykes on Bikes, drinking free beer and eating free food, listening to our friends singing with the soul cover band Kyra and the Tender Morsels on the back patio. Rockin' our socks off. Getting drunker than skunks with a lot of tough lesbian chicks, even though we were due at his elderly aunt and uncle's in Palo Alto for dinner later that evening. Seriously wishing we could just hang with the Dykes on Bikes and the Tender Morsels instead.

Neither I, nor Nadja, nor SuperBF are gay. We do not ride bikes. We are not morsels of any variety, tender or not. 

We don't 100% fit in here, but damn -- we try our hardest. Because this is one cool bar.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Pretty boys and trannies, burly bears and grannies.   
Chicks like me are welcome
(I don't think it's random)
Conversations roaring
Burly bears are scoring
I just love the crowd
Music's not too loud
Plus it's very varied
Bartenders not harried
Kinda meet and mingle
Gay men all a-tingle
okay I'm outta rhymes
but the Eagle Tavern
was
good
times.
author: Valentina D.

description:
This is an amended review, because in my previous review, I had said that one bartender was not friendly to women, when in fact I totally misunderstood the guy, and hope he accepts my apology...A couple of women friends had told me that I was wrong about him, and then last night he talked to me about it, and was a complete gentleman about it, even though it really offended him that I said he was sexist, because he is in fact not at all sexist, but has a lot of women in his life. 

This is a great bar....Music is excellent- not that discoey crap...The Cramps, Led Zepplin...even some oldies...all stuff I like....They have bands on Thursday nights....Sunday beer busts are butt to butt packed but fun. It's also a great place to bring a pack of people on a Saturday night- there's plenty of room and it's not obnoxiously crowded for a Saturday. You can hang out in the large back area and smoke, and be in the sun, so you don't have that feeling of being in a dark bar during the day. 

This place is also very woman friendly- so it's one of the few gay bars in SF where both men women, gay and straight hang, and get along , and are not isolated from one another.
author: Nick M.

description:
66 reviews -- What more can I say about this gay, biker, leather bar that hasn't been said already?

Great bar, friendly staff, good sized patio with heaters, and dog friendly. Just stay away from the bathroom with no lock, unless of course, you're looking for some action.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Want to see a broad cross section of queers that live in SF? 

Sunday beer bust is where it's at. From bears, jocks, leather, tweakers, twinks, lesbians, hipsters - they're all here (it's kinda like the movie the Breakfast Club, but everyone's drinking and not fighting).

Thursday nights can be just as varied, but throw in some straights who don't mind trekking to a gay bar to listen to live music.
author: Sean G.

description:
Well, it's kinda hard for me to review this bar. I've danced on it, played the stage, puked in corners, been naked, pissed in jars in the DJ booth, shown my bush in order to get happy hour prices on beard night,  and once got kissed by one of the owners to show me that gay men kiss better. To be fair, I'd just say that he didn't prove that gay guys kiss better, he proved that maybe gay BIKERS kiss better, but that's another story. 

This bar was taken over by its current owners because the Hole was, at the time, getting taken over by Castro boys, and they needed to take the party elsewhere. But they went hog wild. These two men KNOW what a bar shoud be like. 

Amongst the many special touches are the benches out on the patio. Notice that they're cut into three slabs. That middle slab? The thin one? Was built deliberately to have some give. This is so your ass doesn't get sore from sitting on some unforgiving, flat bench. Also note the heat lamps above so's you don't freeze said ass off in the colder months.  

The driftwood chair's got a drink tray and it and the gearhead fountain next to it were made by one of the owners. And it's fun to straddle the fence above the grill and spit into the fire. 

Beer bust on Sundays is really more for the nouveau leather boy crew, in my experience---but I haven't been to a beer bust here in so long who knows what goes on now.

Anyways, it's a home away from home. Really, i'm just still trying to get my name on a plaque in front of one of the seats at the end of the bar. I'll probably have to die.
author: SheRat R.

description: By the way, Joe the bartender is smoking hot and really nice. So when you need a place with a lusty buzz, head to the back patio, behold his studly-ness and order a stiff one from him.
author: Malcolm K.

description: The Sunday afternoon beer bust still caters primarily to the leather and Levis crowd that gravitated here for years, but any other time of the week this is an authentic freak show. Tweakers, stoners, ZZ Top lookalikes, skateboarders with pants hanging down to there, tattooed skinheads, goths, punk rockers, and assorted creatures only Edward Gorey could have imagined make up the general population of this one-time SOMA institution that was a hot spot long before SOMA got hot. How could something so good turn so bad?
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Yeah.  Fuck Yeah.  This is what America is all about.  When I used to work in the neighborhood my coworker and I would skip out of work to get martinis here.  At like, 2 in the afternoon.  Because it was the closest bar that was open.  And because of the fucking bitching patio.  I could see how it could be annoying during a leather party, but on a Tuesday afternoon and it's just you and the bartenders, and the sun is shining, all is right with the world.  

And, their Thursday Night Live music night consistently has really awesome programming.  I've only made it there once, but I always get antsy when I read their calendar because it's always something out the ordinary and super rad.  Basically, if you go there on Thursday nights a lot, we should probably hang out.
author: Coco D.

description:
Why?  Beer Bust, of course.  Pay the token charge at the door then step into a swirling world of moustached men and beer.  Dress as you like, because they all did---no need to be too shy.  Squeeze your way through the solid wall of men and leather to the bar with your plastic cup and a glorious Sunday afternoon has begun.

The giant patio is a lavish luxury in San Francisco, and it's stage area adds a nice height for manwatching across the lower level.  The DJ plays decent music, but it's not nearly as loud as the roar of all those men laughing and talking.

The beer is watery and cheap, but who cares!  At four of them, you break even on your cover charge, and the rest is icing on the cake---or head on the beer.  When you haven't a care in the world, you're in San Francisco, and it happens to be Sunday around 3:00, get over there.
author: Randy F.

description: i'm a straight girl who brought her boyfriend. We loved it!. Free vinyl! Cheap pitchers! mirrored urinals!
author: Blis L.

description: Beer bust is surprisingly fun and people are pretty friendly.  I went here back in the 90s where the staff was more "leather lifestyle".  Now they have some nice staff, but also steroided bartenders who think that the customer is most likely wrong. I was told that I was yelling at the fellow and that it was bad form!  Maybe he's a special needs bartender?
author: David C.

description: kinda friendly, hot hunky smart bartenders, older men welcome,. They need to have a Saturday beer bust etc.
author: Richard M.

description:
It seems like most big cities have their version of the Eagle--often called the Eagle--but I have to prefer ours best. It's a leather bar. It's a dive bar. It's a... big space with a brick BBQ fire pit. The Eagle truly attracts all types and doesn't bat an eyelash at, well, anything. 

Like many, I make an almost weekly pilgrimage to SoMa for their anything-goes Sunday beer bust. It's probably some of the most fun you can have in San Francisco with alcohol in public. Sure it's a terrific value, per se, but that's not what you're really thinking as you chug down beer #5 as you scarf another hot dog while waiting for the porta-pottie, right? Right?
author: Aaron L.

description:
I'm always perturbed going to the Eagle for their Sunday beer bust. Although half of the space is outside, I can't seem to shake off the creeping smell which lingers in and out.

Is that cheap beer, ass, bbq, ass, dudes who haven't showered for days, or ass?

Some things are better left undiscovered.

I do fancy the all you can drink beer for like $10 and the free bbq on Sundays. Oh, the music rocks too!
author: Jonny M.

description:
Probably the most endearing gay bar in San Francisco.  The crowd is always fun (and yes - as someone mention they can be a little weird).  They also play rock music!  Yeah!  Live and otherwise.  

I love people watching here and I love getting drunk at the beer bust here even more!
author: Daniel H.

description:
I have three favorite things about the Eagle:
1) Tastycakes the Bartender. He's amazing, he has such a lovely energy and enthusiasm that precious few SOMA Bartenders can match. Sometimes I just want to shake him until he's blurry, especially after a long day of work and you walk in and he warms you right up and makes everything right as rain. Very few people can do that and he's definitely an asset. 
2) Thursday Night Live. What an awesome event. It's mixed crowd, so you get your gays, your lesbians and straight peoples all mixed together to live music. I'm sure there's a lot of crossover too, cuz some of them straight nerdy boys that wander in from the Mission ... let's just say I'm glad Eagle has this night. Anything to get my recruitment quota up. I just need two more straight to gay conversions and Ellen DeGeneres will send me a toaster oven!
3) Speaking of straight people... One of my favorite things to do is take straight friends from out of town into the middle room between the inside and the patio and tell them to look at the hundreds of dirty jock straps and underwear that hang from the ceiling. It's a great way to welcome them to San Francisco from parts Puritan, because really, there's nothing more quintessentially San Francisco than that.
author: scott r.

description:
Lotsamen. Lotsa furry men. Lots furry men dressed in leather. 

No issues with the previously described crowd at The Eagle - don't get me wrong. It's just a lot to soak in on a mellow Sunday afternoon. Although, I guess Beer Bust Sundays aren't supposed to be mellow ($10 all you can drink beer for 3 hours). 

While it was completely a good time, I don't think The Eagle is my scene. I'm more of a BOC girl, I guess. *sigh* I really am Grace Adler...
author: Deann M.

description:
I've been here a handful of times, but each time, it's a memorable occasion. 

The first time, I saw Raunchy Reckless & the Amazons, a Xena tribute band. Their hit song is What Would Xena Do? Words to live by. 

The 2nd time, I was on my first date with a priest. (Okay, really a pastor, whatever, priest sounds cooler, right?) So naturally, we go to the bear bar & no one had the slightest problem with the straight couple making out. Very open-minded. Of course, they didn't know he was a priest, I guess. 

Most recently I saw the Guy-Guys there, an all guys Go-Go's cover band, kind of like a cross between the Go-Go's and maybe the New York Dolls, only crazier. Totally awesome. 

Space out back with a fire. And, added bonus, you can usually find parking nearby, though I wouldn't vouch for the safety of the neighborhood.

UPDATE - The Eagle was the venue for my band's first gig. We had a great time, the bartender/sound guy was incredibly patient with my nervous first-time micro-managing, the stage was ample for our needs, the audience seemed happy with the ambience, drinks, and back patio. Loved playing there! 

Only complaint - the fact that people have to go across the stage to get to the bathroom...which, incidentally, does not have a door.
author: Melinda K.

description: Surly attitude from douchebag bartender at main bar.  If you don't look like a bear or a leather daddy forget it, the service is going to suck! There are many other bars in the area that are much friendlier.  This is the Hamburger Mary's of bars... and you know what's happening to them!
author: Mike E.

description:
Great place to go on a hot Sunday afternoon to celebrate your completion of the dreaded but required laundry chores that morning! I have been going off and on here for years and I have to say that it is rather consistent in its loyalty to provide a good time. Sunday beer bust are always packed, the best music (metal and rock n roll, thank god), and the occasional "show" for mature audiences only, well semi mature... Huge patio with a bar in the back. fire pit, stage area. During festivals and holidays there can be a line out from to get in. Two man enter...one man leave...or vise versa...

Thursdays can be quite interesting when the bands start to play. One Thursday a couple of years ago I thought I heard a "the new genre" of music here....stuffed animals jumping around playing wacky beats obviously on some sort of supplements, but it was interesting and well received as a good night. 

Most other nights (except Sundays & Thursdays, see above) is a hit or miss, or quite frankly dead in bar terms...they do however have some occasional fundrasier here so you never know...

Though I am not a part the leather community and have no intentions of joining (hey, my mother reads Yelp...O...K!) but a key "must not miss party" is the Golden Dildo Awards that coincide with the Golden Globe Awards...find out who will get the award for "Best Double Penetration" . It is a hoot! ;-) Good times, good times. 

The Eagle Tavern: Its oh so gay, but sometimes straight San Francisco done oh so right. Its really just a San Francisco place. Dirty is some spots but surprisingly charming and comfortble, like the city herself.

No labels...No lube...No mercy....that should be their slogan! Everyone but minors and toddlers are welcome...
author: Terry S.

description:
This is less a review of the Eagle--which I love, and the beer bust pretty much anchors my week--than a caution to any normal girls who ain't dangerous or tough and who may feel the need to review the Eagle.

If you are saddened to find yourself wishing the cute boys around you aren't straight, like to drink blueberry vodka drinks, are weirded out by fetishistic spectacles on a school night OR find men over 40 inherently creepy, please go elsewhere.  Stay above Union or, if you must play fruit fly for the evening, west of Noe.  

Rough chicks are rad.  Kthxbai!

(I'm going to get a blueberry molotov through my yelp profile, I know).
author: Pete K.

description: Cool gay bar to go to once in a blue moon.  Just make sure you like the event they are having.
author: Cynthia B.

description: After visiting Wicked Grounds earlier in the day we ended the night touring another endangered landmark, the Eagle.  I've been to leather bars all over the country (in fact this is my third "Eagle") and this one tops the list.  The décor is spot on (love the jock straps hanging from the ceiling) the bartenders generous pourers.  Especially loved the patio where folks could mingle and still enjoy their cigars and libations.  San Francisco, please save the Eagle!
author: Jonny S.

description: Well, the old Eagle was closed for a long time and the new one is no longer an insult to the range of excellent draft beers San Francisco can provide. I recommend it. They also have good live bands which attract a straight crowd and I enjoy the fact that it doesn't feel like a meat market.
author: L I.

description:
Need a good place to watch some live music on weeknight?  Looking for a place where the Bears roam free and the staff is super nice?  Trying to find a great patio where you can enjoy a beer under the stars on these warm summer nights?  

Look no further.  The Eagle Tavern is your spot.  I love the staff here and the drinks are good and STRONG.  

Just a note: if you're a chick, your bathroom is located stage left.  So don't be shy, just walk around the band and do your business.  Don't worry, there's a door.  : )
author: Jessica B.

description:
it's not particularly gay on nights that local bands play, save for the fuzzy bears that work there, and everybody's nice. the location is well situated with decent parking around, the place is friendly and inviting, and has a great outdoor area, sort of like a courtyard, that is all feel good. my friends' band played there and we had a great time. The bar area is pretty big, leaving the area in front of the stage a little small, so it's maybe not super great as a venue to see your favorite band as much as to hang out and soak up the atmosphere. But it's got plenty of that.

Love how the bathrooms are up on stage, so if you gotta go, everybody's gonna know about it.
author: Henry Y.

description:
Disclaimer: hardcore leather/fetish/BDSM kink scares me. I'm pretty vanilla, but try to keep an open mind about what other people might enjoy. I just know that I'm not into all that stuff, it does nothing for me but make me uncomfortable.

That said, I've come to really enjoy ET on the couple if occasions I've been there. I love the patio (the only time I even venture inside is when I need a refill) and I've met some mellow and great people here.

On the other hand, I've been aggressively sniffed and groped by a complete stranger who doesn't get the concept of "not interested" and had an experience where it took everything in my power to use the restroom without getting pulled into some sort of watersports activity. (Seriously, I don't care if you get off on the golden showers stuff, but wouldn't you *ask* before placing any part of your body in the path of someone else's stream?!?)

The bartenders are cool, but if you're not friendly with them you can be ignored for a while. I've been by on a couple Thursday nights when they had bands playing and mostly ignored the music, nothing seemed especially spectacular about it. Anyway, I kind of prefer this place on nights when there isn't a lot going on.
author: Jere K.

description:
This might be my favorite bar in SF, if for no other reason than the back patio. It helps that the staff are friendly, the drinks strong, and the chances of witnessing public sex is at least 1 in 3. I'm a voyeuristic stoner pervert so The Eagle is pretty much my dream bar. 

Note: I hate crowds so you won't find me there on Sunday's during beer bust or on any gay holiday - Folsom, Dore Alley, Pride, etc. Should you dare to venture in during those times be prepared for the assault of wall-to-wall sweaty man ass on all six of your senses.
author: Prattle P.

description:
Gay, edgy, freaky, leather, rubber, bear, biker fun bar. Hands down, the best damn patio in the city to hang out and drink. You really need to appreciate all kinds of people to enjoy yourself here.

It can be pretty empty at times, but it is always a party for Sunday Beer Busts that start at 3 and benefit one non-profit or another. Damn crazy on Folsom, Up-Your-Alley, and Hairrison Fair days.

The music, is, how shall I say it... educational. Never boring, sometimes too loud. It is integral to the experience and wouldn't ask them to change it. It's my favorite hangout in the city.
author: AJ A.

description:
The SF gay community  assembles here on Sunday afternoon.  Once orthodox leather - now more of a buzzed, multifarious.
Once more of a must stop for local politicians interested in the gay vote -  .... All proceeds each Sunday benefit local non-profits and charities.  The various and sundry groups take turn running the weekly soiree - the rodeo club served some awesome tri-tip steaks on the massive brick grill.  Hot-dogs are the fare most of the time. Beer flows 3-6pm shirp.   $10 - the queen of cheap dates
author: John L.

description:
I'm not into leather, I'm not into crowds and my tasty drink offerings are Beer, ok, then what am I doing here on a sunday afternoon? Well I am trying to give it another chance after having been here on a Friday night some years back and swearing never again.
Hence, never again never sounded so good.
author: Sean S.

description:
Whats not to love about being shoulder to shoulder, belly to belly with a sea of big hairy men all boozin' it up on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. 

Sundays are by far the most crowded days at the Eagle because of the $10 beer bust and its expansive back patio.  There are 3 bars open on Sunday, and the line for beer bust goes fast.

The music is sweet, I wouldn't have guesses that Ike and Tina would sweetly be followed by the B-52's, and the Cherry Poppin' Daddies.  The range in music played is expansive, but it works, and keeps my head bobbin as I scope the crowd for hot guys.

Every other day of the week, the Eagle is slow, and mellow, but a nice place to go and get a drink after work if you just want to relax.  Thursday nights the Eagle plays host to no-name, indie label punk and rock bands.  Its a great venue and only a $5 cover.

Sure the crowd mainly caters to the leather and levi's men, but you do find your trannies, punks, castro queens, jocks, skinheads, blue collar men, SF Cheer Squad, and tattoos galore... its a great place to people watch.
author: Bone D.

description:
An institution.

It sunday, need a beer, eagle...need a boot shine...eagle...need a man...eagle..need to be spit on...eagle....

well, you get my drift. 

This place is a living museum, with an ever changing tableau of young and old, pretty and not.
author: Ken p.

description:
Hell Yeah! I've wanted to visit The Eagle Tavern for years and last night I did.

It was a "post holiday party, spur of the minute" decision and I was stoked. The place was pretty empty when we showed up and we quickly sorted that out as at least 20 of us started to arrive. The bartender didn't seem all that enthused to see us but I think he warmed up once he realized we were decent, respectable and respectful.

The decor is great, perfectly summarizing the The Eagle Tavern on all levels. 

My favorite was naturally the outdoor patio, fire pit included. Damn I love these bars! I had a great time catching up with work chums in this mellow environment. I would gladly return to The Eagle Tavern. Til then. . . .
author: alexa c.

description: After Folsom St fair this chick and I were looking for a place to take the edge off.  I'm not a fan of crowded places or talking to strangers. Not really a people person in general. All that being said, the service is excellent and the clientele isn't too chatty. Plus I could chill at the bar with my shirt off. I'm not really a shirt person either.
author: Corey V.

description: I love the Eagle Tavern and the Beer Busts are awesome. Especially the Dykes on Bikes Beer Busts. Parking my Harley on the sidewalk is an added benefit of this fun bar.
